rule: Use "I'm" (I am) to talk about yourself right now.
example:
✓ I'm hot! (I am hot)
✗ I hot! (missing "am")
question: Can you turn on the aircon, please? ______

rule: Use "isn't" (is not) for negative sentences with he/she/it.
example:
✓ Emma isn't interested in video games.
✗ Emma not interested in video games.
question: Emma ______ in playing video games.

rule: In questions, put "is" BEFORE the subject (person/thing).
example:
✓ Is your brother at home?
✗ Is at home your brother? (wrong order)
question: '______?' 'No, he's at school.'

rule: Use "How much are they?" to ask about price (plural things).
example:
✓ How much are they? (asking price of toys)
✗ How much they are? (wrong question order)
question: These toys are cool. ______?

rule: Use "is/are + verb-ing" for actions happening RIGHT NOW.
example:
✓ Look! She is wearing a pink backpack. (now)
✗ Look! She wearing a pink backpack. (missing "is")
question: Look, there's Amy. ______ a pink backpack.

rule: Use "I'm not + verb-ing" for negative present continuous.
example:
✓ I'm not watching TV. (not now)
✗ I don't watching TV. (wrong form)
question: You can turn off the TV. ______ it.

topic: Are you doing? (present continuous questions) + be/have/do
rule: For present continuous questions: Is + subject + verb-ing?
example:
✓ Is Ben swimming today?
✗ Is swimming Ben? (wrong order)
question: '______ today?' 'No, he's staying home.'

topic: Are you doing? (present continuous questions) + be/have/do
rule: Question word + is/are + subject + verb-ing?
example:
✓ Where is she going?
✓ Where's she going? (short form)
question: Look, there's Katie! ______?

rule: Add "-s" or "-es" to verbs with he/she/it in present simple.
example:
✓ The MTR goes to Tung Chung. (goes, not go)
✗ The MTR go to Tung Chung.
question: The MTR ______ to Tung Chung every day.

rule: Put frequency words (often, usually, always) BEFORE the main verb.
example:
✓ We often go to the park. (often before go)
✗ We go often to the park. (wrong position)
question: We ______ to the park on Sundays.

rule: Use "don't" + verb (we/you/they) for negative present simple.
example:
✓ We don't use tablets often.
✗ We doesn't use tablets often. (doesn't is wrong with "we")
question: We ______ tablets at school very often.

rule: Use "Do you + verb?" for present simple questions.
example:
✓ Do you play basketball?
✗ Are you play basketball? (use Do, not Are)
question: '______ basketball?' 'Yes, but I'm not very good.'

rule: Question word + does + subject + verb (not verb-s)?
example:
✓ What does this word mean?
✗ What means this word? (wrong order)
question: I don't understand this maths problem. What ______?

topic: I am doing and I do + be/have/do
rule: Use "I'm doing" for actions happening NOW. Use "I do" for regular actions.
example:
✓ I'm doing my homework. (now)
✓ I do my homework every day. (regular)
question: Please be quiet. ______ my homework.

topic: I am doing and I do + have
rule: Use "has" (not have) with he/she/it for regular actions.
example:
✓ Tommy has breakfast every morning. (regular)
✗ Tommy have breakfast. (needs "has" with he)
question: Tommy ______ breakfast before school every morning.

topic: I am doing and I do + be/have/do
rule: Use "do you usually do" for questions about regular actions.
example:
✓ What do you usually do after school? (regular habit)
✗ What are you usually doing? (wrong for habits)
question: What ______ after school?

topic: I have... and I've got + have
rule: British English: Both "has" and "has got" mean possession (same!).
example:
✓ She has a headache. (British style 1)
✓ She's got a headache. (British style 2)
Both are correct!
question: Sarah isn't feeling well. ______ a headache.

topic: I have... and I've got + have
rule: British English: Use "haven't got" OR "don't have" for negative.
example:
✓ They haven't got any pets. (British style 1)
✓ They don't have any pets. (British style 2)
question: They ______ any pets at home.

rule: Use "was/were" (not am/is/are) to talk about the past.
example:
✓ The weather was sunny. (past)
✗ The weather is sunny. (present, not past)
question: The weather ______ during Chinese New Year.

rule: In past questions, put "were/was" BEFORE the subject.
example:
✓ Why were you late?
✗ Why you were late? (wrong question order)
question: Why ______ late for school this morning?

rule: Use past form (worked, went, studied) to talk about finished past actions.
example:
✓ My sister worked at Ocean Park. (past)
✗ My sister work at Ocean Park. (needs past form)
question: My sister ______ at Ocean Park from 2018 to 2023.

rule: Use past form of irregular verbs: go → went (not goed).
example:
✓ Michael went to the pool. (went = past of go)
✗ Michael goed to the pool. (no such word!)
question: Michael ______ to the swimming pool three times last week.

rule: Use "didn't + verb" (NOT didn't + past verb) for past negative.
example:
✓ I didn't play games. (didn't + play)
✗ I didn't played games. (don't use past after didn't)
question: I ______ video games yesterday.

rule: In past questions: did + subject + verb (not past verb)?
example:
✓ How did the accident happen? (did + happen)
✗ How did the accident happened? (no past after did)
question: 'How ______?' 'I don't know. I didn't see it.'

rule: Use "was/were + verb-ing" for actions in progress in the past.
example:
✓ What were you doing at 3 o'clock? (action in progress)
✗ What did you do at 3 o'clock? (completed action, different meaning)
question: What ______ at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon?

topic: I was doing and I did
rule: When one action interrupts another: past continuous + past simple.
example:
✓ He was reading when his phone rang.
(was reading = in progress, rang = interruption)
question: Jack was reading a comic book when his phone ______.

topic: I was doing and I did
rule: Use "were/was + verb-ing" for ongoing action when you saw it.
example:
✓ They were waiting. (I saw them in the middle of waiting)
✗ They waited. (completed action, different meaning)
question: I saw Lucy and Kevin this morning. They ______ at the MTR station.

rule: Use "has/have + past participle" for recent actions with present result.
example:
✓ She's gone to bed. (she's in bed NOW, result of going)
✗ She went to bed. (just stating past fact, no present result)
question: 'Where's Rebecca?' '______ to bed.'

rule: Use "haven't arrived yet" to say something hasn't happened (but we expected it).
example:
✓ They haven't arrived yet. (still waiting for them)
✗ They don't arrive yet. (wrong tense)
question: 'Are Laura and Paul here?' 'No, they ______.'

rule:
Use "has/have + never + past participle" for life experiences.
Remember: travel → travelled (British spelling with double L)
example:
✓ She has never travelled by plane. (in her life)
✗ She never travelled. (missing "has")
question: My brother ______ on a plane.

rule: Present perfect: see → seen (NOT saw).
example:
✓ I've seen that teacher before. (I've seen = I have seen)
✗ I've saw that teacher. (wrong past participle)
question: ______ that teacher before, but I can't remember where.

rule: Use "have you been" (NOT are you) with "How long" for duration.
example:
✓ How long have you been friends? (duration until now)
✗ How long are you friends? (wrong tense)
question: 'How long ______ friends?' 'Since Primary 1.'

rule: Use "I've known" (NOT I know) for "how long" situations continuing to now.
example:
✓ I've known her for ages. (still know her now)
✗ I know her for ages. (wrong tense for duration)
question: 'Do you know Lisa?' 'Yes, ______ her for a long time.'

topic: for, since, ago + from... to, until, since
rule: Use "for + period of time" with present perfect (not "since + period").
example:
✓ for six months (duration)
✗ since six months (wrong preposition)
question: Richard has been in Hong Kong ______.

rule: Use "ago" (NOT for/since) to say when something happened.
example:
✓ Ten minutes ago. (saying when)
✗ For ten minutes. (saying how long)
question: 'When did Tom leave?' '______'

topic: I have done and I did
rule: Use past simple (NOT present perfect) with specific past time (last year, yesterday).
example:
✓ We didn't have a trip last summer. (specific time = past simple)
✗ We haven't had a trip last summer. (can't use with "last summer")
question: We ______ a family trip last summer.

topic: I have done and I did
rule: Use past simple (were) with specific past time, NOT present perfect.
example:
✓ Where were you on Sunday? (specific time)
✗ Where have you been on Sunday? (wrong with specific time)
question: Where ______ on Sunday afternoon? I couldn't find you.

rule: Passive: was/were + past participle (built, made, opened).
example:
✓ This school was built 50 years ago.
✗ This school built 50 years ago. (missing "was")
question: This school ______ 50 years ago.

rule: Passive negative: weren't/wasn't + past participle.
example:
✓ We weren't invited. (passive)
✗ We didn't invite. (active, different meaning)
question: We ______ to the birthday party last week.

rule: Passive questions: Where were you born? (NOT Where did you born?)
example:
✓ Where were you born?
✗ Where did you born? (passive needs "were", not "did")
question: 'Where ______ born?' 'In Hong Kong.'

topic: is being done, has been done
rule: Passive continuous: is/are being + past participle.
example:
✓ It is being repaired. (repair in progress now)
✗ It is repairing. (wrong form)
question: My bicycle is at the shop. It ______.

topic: is being done, has been done
rule: Present perfect passive: has/have been + past participle.
example:
✓ It's been stolen. (has been stolen)
✗ It's stolen. (simple present, wrong for completed action)
question: I can't find my pencil case. I think ______.

topic: be/have/do in present and past tenses
rule: Past continuous: wasn't/weren't + verb-ing.
example:
✓ It wasn't raining. (past continuous)
✗ It didn't raining. (wrong form)
question: It ______, so we didn't need our umbrellas.

rule: Present perfect: has/have + past participle. Break → broken (NOT broke).
example:
✓ has broken (present perfect)
✗ has broke (wrong form)
question: Somebody ______ this window.

rule: Use present continuous (am/is/are + verb-ing) for definite future plans.
example:
✓ Andrew is playing football tomorrow. (definite plan)
✗ Andrew play football tomorrow. (needs future form)
question: Andrew ______ football tomorrow.

rule: Use "Are you going...?" for questions about future plans.
example:
✓ Are you going to Ocean Park tonight?
✗ Do you go to Ocean Park tonight? (not for future plans)
question: ______ to Ocean Park tonight?

rule: Use present simple for timetables/schedules (starts, begins, opens).
example:
✓ The film starts at 7:30. (timetable)
✗ The film is starting at 7:30. (unusual for timetable)
question: 'What time is the film tonight?' 'It ______ at 7:30.'

rule: Use "going to + verb" for future intentions and plans.
example:
✓ What are you going to bring?
✗ What do you bring? (not clear it's future)
question: What ______ to the school picnic next week?

rule: Use "will + verb" for predictions.
example:
✓ Kelly will pass the test. (prediction)
✗ Kelly passes the test. (wrong for future prediction)
question: I think Kelly ______ the spelling test.

rule: Use present continuous (NOT will) when the plan is already decided.
example:
✓ We're going to Victoria Peak. (already decided)
✗ We'll go to Victoria Peak. (sounds like deciding now)
question: ______ to Victoria Peak on Saturday. Do you want to come with us?

rule: Use "I'll" (I will) when you decide at the moment of speaking.
example:
✓ I'll call you tomorrow. (deciding now)
✗ I'm calling you tomorrow. (sounds already planned)
question: '______ you tomorrow, OK?' 'OK, bye.'

rule: Use present continuous for fixed arrangements.
example:
✓ I'm studying tomorrow. (arranged already)
✗ I'll study tomorrow. (sounds like deciding now)
question: ______ tomorrow, so I can't play with you.

rule: Use "Shall we...?" for suggestions.
example:
✓ Shall we go to the playground?
✗ Do we go to the playground? (not for suggestions)
question: It's a nice day. ______ to the playground?

rule: Use "might/may" for possibilities (not sure).
example:
✓ I might go. (possible, not sure)
✓ I may go. (same meaning)
question: ______ to the swimming pool this evening, but I'm not sure.

rule: Use "Can I...?" or "May I...?" to ask for permission politely.
example:
✓ Can I sit here?
✓ May I sit here? (more formal)
question: '______ here?' 'Yes, of course.'

rule: Use "can't" (NOT couldn't) for present/future inability.
example:
✓ They can't come next week. (future)
✗ They couldn't come next week. (wrong tense)
question: I'm having a birthday party next week, but Paul and Rachel ______.

rule: Use "couldn't" (NOT can't) for past inability.
example:
✓ She couldn't speak Cantonese before. (past)
✗ She can't speak Cantonese before. (wrong tense)
question: Before Maria came to Hong Kong, she ______ speak Cantonese.

topic: must and can't + have to and must
rule: Use "had to" (NOT must) for past obligation.
example:
✓ We had to walk home. (past obligation)
✗ We must walk home. (present, not past)
question: We ______ walk home last night. The MTR had stopped running.

rule: Use "don't need to" to say something is not necessary.
example:
✓ I don't need to go yet.
✗ I mustn't go yet. (means "I must not go", different meaning!)
question: ______ go yet. I can stay a little longer.

rule: Use "should" or "ought to" for advice (both correct!).
example:
✓ You should watch it. (advice)
✓ You ought to watch it. (same meaning)
question: It's a great film. You ______ go and watch it.

rule: Questions with "have to": Do you have to...? (NOT Have you to...?)
example:
✓ What time do you have to go?
✗ What time have you to go? (wrong question form)
question: What time ______ go to your piano lesson tomorrow?

rule: Past negative: didn't have to (NOT hadn't to).
example:
✓ We didn't have to wait long. (past)
✗ We hadn't to wait long. (not standard English)
question: We ______ wait long for the bus - it came in a few minutes.

rule: Use "Would you like...?" for polite offers.
example:
✓ Would you like some bubble tea? (polite offer)
✗ Do you like bubble tea? (asking about general preference)
question: '______ some bubble tea?' 'No, thank you.'

topic: Do this! Don't do that! Let's do this!
rule: Negative imperative: Don't + verb.
example:
✓ Please don't go.
✗ Please you don't go. (no subject in imperatives)
question: Please ______ Stay here with me.

rule: Use "used to + verb" for past habits (not now).
example:
✓ He used to work at a toy shop. (past, not now)
✗ He use to work. (needs "-d": used)
question: Dave ______ at a toy store. Now he works at a bookshop.

rule: Questions with "there": Is there...? (NOT Has there...?)
example:
✓ Is there a 7-Eleven near here?
✗ Has there a 7-Eleven? (wrong form)
question: Excuse me, ______ a 7-Eleven near here?

rule: Use "There are" (NOT They are) for plural things that exist.
example:
✓ There are lots of children at the playground.
✗ They are lots of children. (wrong for existence)
question: ______ lots of children at the playground. It's very crowded.

rule: Use "there wasn't" (NOT it wasn't) for things that didn't exist.
example:
✓ There wasn't anything to eat.
✗ It wasn't anything to eat. (wrong form)
question: I was hungry when I got home, but ______ anything to eat.

rule: Use "It's" (NOT There is) for distance.
example:
✓ It's two kilometres from here to school.
✗ There is two kilometres. (wrong for distance)
question: ______ two kilometres from our flat to the school.

rule: Use "Is it true...?" (NOT Is there true...?) for facts.
example:
✓ Is it true that you're moving?
✗ Is there true? (wrong form)
question: ______ true that you're moving to Kowloon?

rule: Short answers: has/have (NOT is) for "have got".
example:
✓ My brother has. (he's got one)
✗ My brother is. (wrong auxiliary)
question: I haven't got a skateboard, but my brother ______.

rule: Short answers with "like": does (NOT is).
example:
✓ Sue does. (she likes them)
✗ Sue is. (wrong for "like")
question: I don't like rainy days, but Sue ______.

topic: Have you? Are you? Don't you? etc.
rule: Question tags for interest: Did she? (past)
example:
✓ 'She won the spelling bee.' 'Did she?' (showing interest)
✗ 'She won.' 'Has she?' (wrong tense)
question: 'Nicola won the spelling bee last week.' '______? Really?'

topic: Have you? Are you? Don't you? etc.
rule: Question tags: haven't you? (NOT have you?) after positive.
example:
✓ You haven't met my teacher, have you? (negative, positive tag)
✗ You haven't met my teacher, haven't you? (both negative = wrong)
question: You haven't met my teacher, ______?

topic: too, either, so am I, neither do I etc.
rule: Use "either" (NOT too) after negative sentences.
example:
✓ He doesn't read comics either. (after negative)
✗ He doesn't read comics too. (use "either" not "too")
question: Ben doesn't watch cartoons. He doesn't read comic books ______.

topic: too, either, so am I, neither do I etc.
rule: Agreement with "would": So would I (NOT So do I).
example:
✓ 'I'd like to go.' 'So would I.' (matching "would")
✗ 'I'd like to go.' 'So do I.' (wrong auxiliary)
question: 'I'd like to go to Disneyland.' '______.'

rule: Use "doesn't do" (NOT doesn't) for action verbs.
example:
✓ She doesn't do much. (action = "do")
✗ She doesn't much. (needs verb)
question: Sue ______ much on weekends.

topic: is it...? have you...? do they...? etc.
rule: Passive questions: When was... + past participle?
example:
✓ When was the MTR opened? (passive)
✗ When did the MTR open? (active, different meaning)
question: 'When ______?' 'I'm not sure. More than 50 years ago.'

topic: is it...? have you...? do they...? etc.
rule: Use "did you do" (NOT just did you) for "how" questions.
example:
✓ How did you do that? (action = do)
✗ How did you that? (needs verb)
question: 'I hurt my knee last week.' 'How ______ that?'

topic: is it...? have you...? do they...? etc.
rule: Negative questions: Why didn't you...? (NOT Why you didn't...?)
example:
✓ Why didn't you phone me?
✗ Why you didn't phone me? (wrong order)
question: Why ______ me last night? I was waiting for you to call.

topic: Who saw you? Who did you see?
rule: When "who" is the subject: no "do/does" needed.
example:
✓ Who lives in this flat? (subject = who)
✗ Who does live in this flat? (don't need "does")
question: 'Who ______ in this flat?' 'I don't know.'

rule: "What" questions: What did + subject + verb?
example:
✓ What did Paul say?
✗ What said Paul? (need "did" before subject)
question: What ______ when you told him the joke?

rule: Preposition at end: Which hospital is he in? (British style)
example:
✓ Which hospital is he in?
✓ In which hospital is he? (very formal)
question: 'Tom's dad is at the hospital.' '______?'

rule: Use "What was... like?" to ask for description.
example:
✓ What was the weather like?
✗ How was the weather like? (don't use "how" + "like")
question: Did you have a nice trip? ______?

rule: Use "Who is...?" to compare two people.
example:
✓ Who is taller - Ben or Gary?
✗ What is taller? (use "who" for people)
question: ______ taller - Ben or Gary?

topic: How long does it take...? + one/ones
rule: Use "Which one?" (NOT just "Which?") when pointing to specific things.
example:
✓ Which one is yours? (one = pencil)
✓ Which is yours? (also acceptable)
question: There are four pencils here. ______ is yours?

rule: Use "How long does it take...?" for duration questions.
example:
✓ How long does it take to get to Stanley?
✗ How long does it want? (wrong verb)
question: How long ______ to get to Stanley by bus?

topic: Do you know where...? I don't know what... etc.
rule: In indirect questions: subject + verb (NOT verb + subject).
example:
✓ I don't remember what Kate was wearing. (normal order)
✗ I don't remember what was Kate wearing. (wrong order)
question: I don't remember what ______ at the party.

topic: Do you know where...? I don't know what... etc.
rule: Use "if" or "whether" (both OK) for yes/no embedded questions.
example:
✓ Do you know if Jack is at home?
✓ Do you know whether Jack is at home? (same meaning)
question: 'Do you know ______?' 'Yes, I think so.'

topic: She said that... He told me that...
rule: Reported speech: will → would in the past report.
example:
✓ He said (that) he would call. (will → would)
✗ He said he will call. (needs "would" not "will")
question: I saw Steve a week ago. He said that ______ me, but he didn't.

topic: She said that... He told me that...
rule: Use "said (that)" OR "told me" (NOT said me).
example:
✓ He said (that) he was tired. (said + that)
✓ He told me he was tired. (told + me)
✗ He said me he was tired. (can't use "said me")
question: 'Why did Tim go to bed so early?' 'He ______.'

rule: After "shouldn't": use verb (NOT -ing).
example:
✓ You shouldn't do so much homework. (verb)
✗ You shouldn't doing homework. (no -ing after shouldn't)
question: You shouldn't ______ so much homework at once.

rule: After "have to": use verb (NOT to go, NOT going).
example:
✓ I have to go now. (have to + verb)
✗ I have to going now. (no -ing after "have to")
question: It's late. I ______ now.

topic: to... (I want to do) and -ing (I enjoy doing)
rule: After "decide": use "to + verb" (NOT -ing).
example:
✓ She decided to sell her toys. (to + verb)
✗ She decided selling her toys. (wrong form)
question: Tina has decided ______ her old toys.

topic: to... (I want to do) and -ing (I enjoy doing)
rule: After "don't mind": use verb + -ing.
example:
✓ I don't mind waking up early. (verb + -ing)
✗ I don't mind to wake up early. (wrong form)
question: I don't mind ______ early.

topic: to... (I want to do) and -ing (I enjoy doing)
rule: After "like": can use "to + verb" OR "verb + -ing" (both OK!).
example:
✓ Do you like to wake up early? (to + verb)
✓ Do you like waking up early? (verb + -ing)
Both are correct!
question: Do you like ______ early?

topic: I want you to... I told you to...
rule: Pattern: want + person + to + verb.
example:
✓ Do you want me to help you? (want + me + to + help)
✗ Do you want me help you? (missing "to")
question: Do you want ______ you with your homework?

topic: I want you to... I told you to...
rule: After "make": use verb (NOT to + verb).
example:
✓ He makes me laugh. (verb only)
✗ He makes me to laugh. (no "to" after make)
question: He's so funny. He makes ______.

topic: I went to the shop to buy...
rule: Use "to + verb" to show purpose (why you went).
example:
✓ She went to get some snacks. (purpose)
✗ She went for get some snacks. (use "to" not "for")
question: Paula went to the shop ______ some snacks.

topic: go to..., go on..., go for..., go -ing
rule: Use "go for a swim" OR "go swimming" (both OK!).
example:
✓ Let's go for a swim.
✓ Let's go swimming.
✗ Let's for a swim. (needs "go")
question: It's a nice day. Let's ______ for a swim.

rule: Use "get better" (NOT have/make better) for health.
example:
✓ I hope she gets better soon. (health)
✗ I hope she makes better. (wrong verb)
question: I'm sorry your grandma is ill. I hope she ______ better soon.

rule: Use "get in/into" for vehicles you enter.
example:
✓ Kate got into the minibus. (entered)
✗ Kate went into the minibus. (not standard for vehicles)
question: Kate ______ the minibus and went to school.

rule: Use "do" (NOT make) for actions.
example:
✓ I'll do it. (action)
✗ I'll make it. (different meaning - creating something)
question: 'Shall I open the door?' 'No, it's OK. I'll ______.'

rule: Use "make" (NOT do) with "a mistake".
example:
✓ I made a mistake. (fixed expression)
✗ I did a mistake. (wrong verb)
question: I'm sorry. I ______ a mistake on my test.

rule: Use "Did you have...?" for past experiences.
example:
✓ Did you have a good time? (past)
✗ Have you a good time? (wrong question form)
question: ______ a good time at Disneyland?' 'Yes, it was awesome!'

topic: I/me, he/him, they/them etc. + I, me, my, mine
rule: After "have": use "it" (NOT them) for singular things.
example:
✓ You can have it. (singular sticker)
✗ You can have them. (plural, wrong for one sticker)
question: I don't want this sticker. You can have ______.

topic: I/me, he/him, they/them etc. + I, me, my, mine
rule: Use "them" (NOT they) after "with".
example:
✓ Do you want to go with them? (object)
✗ Do you want to go with they? (use "them" not "they")
question: Sue and Kevin are going swimming. Do you want to go with ______?

topic: my/his/their etc. + I, me, my, mine
rule: Use "her" (NOT his/their) for a female person.
example:
✓ I don't know her sister. (Amy's sister)
✗ I don't know his sister. (wrong gender)
question: I know Amy, but I don't know ______ sister.

rule: Use "its" (NOT it's) for possession. It's = it is.
example:
✓ Hong Kong is famous for its skyline. (possession)
✗ Hong Kong is famous for it's skyline. (it's = it is, wrong!)
question: Hong Kong is famous for ______ skyline.

topic: Whose is this? It's mine/yours/hers etc. + I, me, my, mine
rule: Use "hers" when not followed by a noun.
example:
✓ Sarah gave me hers. (no noun after)
✓ Sarah gave me her eraser. (noun after = use "her")
question: I didn't have a rubber, so Sarah gave me ______.

topic: Whose is this? It's mine/yours/hers etc. + I, me, my, mine
rule: Use "mine" (NOT my) after "of".
example:
✓ a friend of mine (possessive)
✗ a friend of my (use "mine" not "my")
question: I went out to meet a friend of ______.

rule: Use "ourselves" (NOT us) to mean "we enjoyed ourselves".
example:
✓ We enjoyed ourselves. (reflexive)
✗ We enjoyed us. (wrong form)
question: We had fun at the beach. We enjoyed ______.

rule: Use "each other" (NOT themselves) for two people doing to each other.
example:
✓ They know each other well. (one knows the other)
✗ They know themselves well. (different meaning - self-knowledge)
question: Kate and Helen are best friends. They know ______ well.

rule: Use "that's" (NOT this is) to respond to news.
example:
✓ 'I'm going to the park.' 'Oh, that's nice!'
✗ 'I'm going to the park.' 'This is nice!' (sounds strange)
question: 'I'm going to the park next week.' 'Oh, ______ nice!'

rule: Use "one" to avoid repeating the noun.
example:
✓ There's one at the end of the street. (one = playground)
✗ There's it at the end. (doesn't replace noun properly)
question: 'Is there a playground near here?' 'Yes, there's ______ at the end of this street.'

rule: Use "a new one" to replace countable singular noun.
example:
✓ Can I have a new one? (one = pencil)
✗ Can I have a new? (needs "one")
question: This pencil is broken. Can I have ______?

rule: Use "some" (NOT any) in positive sentences.
example:
✓ I'm going to buy some school supplies. (positive)
✗ I'm going to buy any school supplies. (use "some")
question: I'm going shopping. I'm going to buy ______ school supplies.

rule: Use "any" (NOT some) in negative sentences.
example:
✓ I don't have any. (negative)
✗ I don't have some. (use "any" in negative)
question: 'Where's your backpack?' 'I don't have ______.'

topic: not + any, no, none + not + anybody/anyone/anything, nobody/no-one/nothing
rule: Can use "have no" OR "don't have any" (both mean the same!).
example:
✓ They have no pets. (no + noun)
✓ They don't have any pets. (not... any)
question: Tracy and Jeff ______ pets.

rule: Use "None" (NOT No) when answering "How much/many".
example:
✓ 'How much money?' 'None.' (no money)
✗ 'How much money?' 'No.' (use "None" not "No")
question: 'How much pocket money do you have?' '______.'

rule: Use "nobody" OR "no-one" (both OK!) when subject of sentence.
example:
✓ There is nobody in the classroom. (subject)
✓ There is no-one in the classroom. (same)
question: There is ______ in the classroom. It's empty.

rule: Use "Nothing" (NOT Anything) for short negative answers.
example:
✓ 'What did you say?' 'Nothing.' (I said nothing)
✗ 'What did you say?' 'Anything.' (doesn't make sense)
question: 'What did you say?' '______.'

rule: Use "something to eat" (NOT for eat).
example:
✓ I want something to eat. (to + verb)
✗ I want something for eat. (use "to" not "for")
question: I'm hungry. I want ______.

rule: Use "every" + singular noun (NOT plural).
example:
✓ every evening (singular)
✗ every evenings (don't use plural after "every")
question: Ben watches TV for about two hours ______.

rule: "Everybody/Everyone" is singular, so use "needs" (NOT need).
example:
✓ Everyone needs friends. (singular verb)
✗ Everyone need friends. (missing -s)
question: ______ need friends.

rule: Use "Most" (NOT Most of) before plural noun without "the".
example:
✓ Most children like games. (no "the")
✗ The most children. (use "the" for superlative only)
question: ______ children like playing games.

rule: Can use "both" OR "both of" before those/these (both OK!).
example:
✓ I like both those toys.
✓ I like both of those toys. (same meaning)
question: I like ______ those toys.

rule: Can use "either" OR "either of" before these/those (both OK!).
example:
✓ I haven't read either these books.
✓ I haven't read either of these books. (same)
question: I haven't read ______ these books.

rule: Can use "a lot of" OR "many" with plural countable nouns (both OK!).
example:
✓ Do you have many classmates?
✓ Do you have a lot of classmates? (same)
question: Do you have ______ classmates?

rule: Use "a lot" (NOT a lot of) without a noun after it.
example:
✓ We go to the cinema a lot. (no noun after)
✗ We go a lot of. (needs noun OR drop "of")
question: We like films, so we go to the cinema ______.

rule: Use "few" (NOT little) with countable plural nouns.
example:
✓ There were few people. (countable)
✗ There were little people. (use "few" for countable)
question: There were ______ people at the beach. It was nearly empty.

rule: "A little" = some (positive meaning) with uncountable nouns.
example:
✓ They have a little money. (some money = positive)
✗ They have little money. (almost no money = negative)
question: They have ______ pocket money, so they're not poor.

rule: Put adjective BEFORE noun in English.
example:
✓ foreign languages (adjective + noun)
✗ languages foreign (wrong order)
question: I don't speak any ______.

rule: Use adverb (quickly) to describe HOW you do something.
example:
✓ He ate quickly. (adverb)
✗ He ate quick. (adjective, wrong form)
question: He ate his lunch very ______.

rule: Use "well" (NOT good) as adverb for "speak".
example:
✓ You speak English very well. (adverb)
✗ You speak English very good. (adjective, wrong)
question: You speak English very ______.

rule: Put "bigger" (comparative) BEFORE noun.
example:
✓ a bigger room (comparative + noun)
✗ a more big room (wrong form)
question: Helen wants ______.

rule: Comparative of bad = worse (NOT more bad).
example:
✓ I feel worse. (comparative of bad)
✗ I feel more bad. (wrong form)
question: 'Do you feel better today?' 'No, I feel ______.'

rule: Use "than" (NOT as/that/of) after comparatives.
example:
✓ The Peak is higher than Kowloon Peak. (comparative + than)
✗ The Peak is higher as Kowloon Peak. (use "than")
question: The Peak is higher ______ Kowloon Peak.

rule: Can use "than him" OR "than he can" after comparative (both OK!).
example:
✓ I can run faster than him. (informal)
✓ I can run faster than he can. (formal, complete)
question: I can run faster ______.

rule: Use "as popular as" for comparisons (NOT popular than).
example:
✓ Swimming isn't as popular as football.
✗ Swimming isn't popular than football. (need "as...as")
question: Swimming isn't ______ football.

rule: Use "the same as" for equality (NOT like/than).
example:
✓ The weather today is the same as yesterday.
✗ The weather today is like yesterday. (informal, less precise)
question: The weather today is the same ______ yesterday.

rule: Superlative: "the most popular attraction" (adjective AFTER "the most").
example:
✓ the most popular attraction (the most + adjective + noun)
✗ the attraction most popular (wrong order)
question: 'The Peak Tram is ______ in Hong Kong.'

rule: Superlative of bad = worst (NOT baddest/most bad).
example:
✓ the worst film (superlative of bad)
✗ the baddest film (wrong form)
question: 'The film was terrible. I think it's ______ film I've ever seen.'

rule: Put "enough" AFTER noun (enough money, NOT money enough).
example:
✓ You've got enough money. (enough + noun)
✗ You've got money enough. (wrong order)
question: Why don't you buy the toy? You've got ______.

rule: Pattern: adjective + enough + to + verb.
example:
✓ good enough to have (adjective + enough + to)
✗ enough good to have (wrong order)
question: Is your English ______ a conversation?

rule: Pattern: too + adjective + to + verb.
example:
✓ too tired to go (too + adjective + to + verb)
✗ too tired for go (use "to" not "for")
question: I'm ______ out.

topic: He speaks English very well. (word order 1)
rule: Word order: subject + verb + object + time.
example:
✓ Sue bought some new shoes yesterday. (object before time)
✗ Sue bought yesterday some new shoes. (time in wrong place)
question: Sue ______. They're very expensive.

rule: Put frequency words BEFORE main verb.
example:
✓ I always drink milk tea. (always before verb)
✗ I drink always milk tea. (wrong position)
question: ______ milk tea in the morning.

rule: With "be": put frequency words AFTER "am/is/are".
example:
✓ They are never at home. (after "are")
✗ They never are at home. (should be after "are")
question: ______ during the day.

rule: Use "yet" (NOT already) in negative sentences.
example:
✓ She isn't here yet. (negative + yet)
✗ She isn't here already. (use "yet" in negative)
question: 'Where's Emma?' 'She ______.'

topic: Give me that book! Give it to me!
rule: Can use "gave Sarah the book" OR "gave the book to Sarah" (both OK!).
example:
✓ I gave Sarah the book.
✓ I gave the book to Sarah. (both correct!)
question: I found the book and I gave ______.

rule: After "when" (future meaning): use present (NOT will).
example:
✓ when I have more time (present for future after "when")
✗ when I'll have more time (don't use "will" after "when")
question: I can't talk to you now. I'll talk to you later when ______ more time.

topic: If we go..., If you see... etc.
rule: After "if" (Type 1): use present (NOT will).
example:
✓ If I'm late... (present after "if")
✗ If I'll be late... (don't use "will" after "if")
question: If ______ late this evening, don't wait for me.

topic: If I had..., If we went... etc.
rule: Type 2 conditional: If + past, ... would + verb.
example:
✓ If I knew, I'd tell you. (imaginary situation)
✗ If I know, I'd tell you. (need past tense after "if")
question: I don't know the answer. If I ______ the answer, I'd tell you.

topic: If I had..., If we went... etc.
rule: Type 2: Use "wasn't" (NOT isn't) after "if" for unreal situations.
example:
✓ If it wasn't expensive, I'd buy it. (unreal/imaginary)
✗ If it isn't expensive... (real situation, different meaning)
question: I like this game. I'd buy it if it ______ so expensive.

topic: a person who..., a thing that/which... (relative clauses 1)
rule: Use "that" OR "which" for things (both OK!). NOT "who" for things.
example:
✓ a flat that is near the MTR (thing)
✓ a flat which is near the MTR (same)
✗ a flat who is... (use "who" only for people)
question: Emma lives in a flat ______ is near the MTR station.

topic: a person who..., a thing that/which... (relative clauses 1)
rule: Use "who" OR "that" for people (both OK!).
example:
✓ children who go to my school (people)
✓ children that go to my school (same)
question: The children ______ go to my school are very friendly.

topic: the people we met, the hotel you stayed at (relative clauses 2)
rule: Can omit "that/which" when it's the object of the clause.
example:
✓ the toys you wanted (omitting "that")
✓ the toys that you wanted (with "that")
Both are correct!
question: Did you find the toys ______?

topic: the people we met, the hotel you stayed at (relative clauses 2)
rule: Use "who" (NOT which/she) for people in relative clauses.
example:
✓ a teacher who can speak four languages
✗ a teacher which can... (use "who" for people)
question: I met ______ can speak four languages.

topic: at 8 o'clock, on Monday, in April etc.
rule: Use "on" before days of the week.
example:
✓ See you on Friday! (on + day)
✗ See you in Friday! (use "on" not "in")
question: Bye! I'll see you ______.

topic: at 8 o'clock, on Monday, in April etc.
rule: Use "in" before period of time (minutes, hours, days).
example:
✓ The bus leaves in five minutes. (future time)
✗ The bus leaves at five minutes. (use "in" for duration)
question: Hurry! The school bus leaves ______ five minutes.

rule: Use "until" OR "till" (both OK!) to mean "up to that time".
example:
✓ I'll be away until Monday. (up to Monday)
✓ I'll be away till Monday. (same meaning)
question: 'How long will you be away?' '______ Monday.'

rule: Use "for" + period of time.
example:
✓ We played for two hours. (duration)
✗ We played during two hours. (use "for" with duration)
question: We played football yesterday. We played ______ two hours.

rule: After "before": use verb + -ing (NOT to + verb).
example:
✓ before going to school (verb + -ing)
✗ before to go to school (don't use "to")
question: I always have breakfast before ______ to school.

rule: Use "at" for position (at the top, at the bottom).
example:
✓ Write your name at the top. (position)
✗ Write your name on the top. (different meaning)
question: Write your name ______ the top of the page.

rule: Use "in" for things surrounded by something.
example:
✓ There are monkeys in those trees. (surrounded by branches)
✗ There are monkeys on those trees. (sounds like surface)
question: There are lots of monkeys ______ those trees.

rule: Use "in" before "the world".
example:
✓ the tallest building in the world
✗ the tallest building on the world (use "in")
question: What's the tallest building ______ the world?

rule: Use "on" before "floor".
example:
✓ on the second floor
✗ in the second floor (use "on")
question: The library is ______ the second floor.

rule: Use "at" before "party/meeting/event".
example:
✓ I met lots of kids at the party. (event)
✗ I met kids in the party. (use "at")
question: I met a lot of kids ______ the birthday party.

rule: Use "to" (NOT in/at) after "go" before places.
example:
✓ I want to go to Japan. (movement)
✗ I want to go in Japan. (use "to")
question: I want to go ______ Japan next year.

rule: Use "at" after "arrive" before specific places.
example:
✓ arrive at Ocean Park (specific place)
✗ arrive to Ocean Park (use "at" not "to")
question: What time did you arrive ______ Ocean Park?

rule: Use "in front of" (NOT at front of).
example:
✓ He's in front of Laura. (in front of)
✗ He's at front of Laura. (need "in" not "at")
question: 'Where is David in this photo?' 'He's ______ Laura.'

rule: Use "over" to mean "going above and across".
example:
✓ I jumped over the fence. (above and across)
✗ I jumped on the fence. (different meaning - onto surface)
question: I jumped ______ the fence into the playground.

rule: British English: use "on holiday" (NOT in holiday).
example:
✓ She's on holiday. (British)
✗ She's in holiday. (use "on")
question: Jane isn't at school this week. She's ______ holiday.

rule: Use "by" + transport (NOT with/in).
example:
✓ by the MTR (transport method)
✗ with the MTR (use "by")
question: Do you like travelling ______ the MTR?

rule: Use "good at" + verb-ing.
example:
✓ I'm good at telling stories. (at + -ing)
✗ I'm good on telling stories. (use "at" not "on")
question: I'm not very good ______ telling stories.

rule: After "without": use verb + -ing (NOT to + verb).
example:
✓ without saying goodbye (verb + -ing)
✗ without to say goodbye (don't use "to")
question: Tom left without ______ goodbye.

topic: listen to..., look at... etc. (verb + preposition)
rule: Use "phone" + person (NO "to" needed in modern English).
example:
✓ I have to phone my parents. (no preposition)
✗ I have to phone to my parents. (don't need "to")
question: I have to phone ______ today.

topic: listen to..., look at... etc. (verb + preposition)
rule: Use "depends on" (NOT depends of/in).
example:
✓ It depends on the restaurant. (depends on)
✗ It depends of the restaurant. (use "on" not "of")
question: 'Do you like eating dim sum?' 'It depends ______ the restaurant.'

topic: go in, fall off, run away etc. (phrasal verbs 1)
rule: Use "get off" for leaving buses/trains.
example:
✓ A student got off the bus. (leaving)
✗ A student got out the bus. (need "of" or use "off")
question: The bus stopped and a student got ______.

topic: put on your shoes, put your shoes on (phrasal verbs 2)
rule: Can say "put on my jacket" OR "put my jacket on" (both OK!).
example:
✓ I put on my jacket. (verb + particle + noun)
✓ I put my jacket on. (verb + noun + particle)
Both are correct!
question: It was cold, so I ______ my jacket ______.

topic: put on your shoes, put your shoes on (phrasal verbs 2)
rule: With pronoun (it): MUST put pronoun between verb and particle.
example:
✓ give it back (pronoun between)
✗ give back it (wrong position)
question: I've got Rachel's pencil. I have to ______ to her.
